thread.title_full: Imelda Staunton wins best performance at the UK Theatre Awards for Gypsy

title: Imelda Staunton wins best performance at the UK Theatre Awards for Gypsy
text:
Imelda Staunton wins best performance at the UK Theatre Awards for Gypsy Imelda Staunton wins best performance at the UK Theatre Awards for Gypsy 
Press Association 2014 / / National Entertainment News Share 
Imelda Staunton has won best performance in a musical for her role in Gypsy at the UK Theatre Awards 2015. 
The show is loosely based on famous striptease artist Gypsy Rose Lee and features music by Jule Styne and lyrics by Stephen Sondheim. 
The acclaimed star plays Momma Rose, the archetypal showbusiness mother, in the production which transferred to London’s West End after a successful run in Chichester. Imelda Staunton with the cast of Gypsy (UK Theatre) 
Reviews for Gypsy, which also won best musical production at the UK Theatre Awards, have been very good, but critics have especially lauded Imelda’s performance. 
Variety said the 59-year-old gives “a helluva performance” and The Guardian hailed “a superb piece of acting”. 
The UK Theatre Awards honour outstanding achievement in performing, producing and management in theatres throughout the country, the only awards ceremony to do so. Dame Eileen Atkins (Matt Sayles/AP) 
On the night, Dame Eileen Atkins was awarded the prestigious Gielgud Award for excellence in the dramatic arts. 
The veteran of stage and screen is best known for co-creating Upstairs Downstairs and The House Of Eliott with Jean Marsh. Dame Eileen has worked across theatre, film and television since the 1950s. Promoted stories Principal dancers in Matthew Bourne’s ballet Swan Lake (Zak Hussein/PA) 
Choreographer Matthew Bourne received The Stage award for outstanding contribution to British theatre. 
The awards were presented at London’s historic Guildhall, with a performance from the cast of The Secret Diary Of Adrian Mole Aged 13-and-three-quarters and appearances from guest presenters. 
Other winners included Gary Owen’s Iphigenia In Splott which took home best new play. 
— Matthew Bourne (@Mattbourne1) October 14, 2015 
Best performance in a play was shared by Polly Lister for Abigail’s Party and Joel MacCormack for Each His Own Wilderness. 
The award for best supporting performance was given to Justine Mitchell in For Services Rendered. 
Ned Bennett received the award for best director for Pomona, while best touring production was won by Twelfth Night, a co-production between English Touring Theatre and Sheffield Theatres.
